Bhutan is gradually opening up.    Starting April 4, schools of Classes VII, VIII, IX, X and XII must open in the first phase.     Primary schools (Classes PP to VI) will start from April 18. However, children who are unvaccinated, and the day care and ECCD centres, must wait for another 10 days to resume.    All colleges and institutions must open from April 4 or soon after, based on the preparation time required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

Schools have been open for class X and XII students to complete their exams.    All schools across the country are to open on April 25th to allow children to attain full immunity after the second dose of vaccination in the first week of April.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Bhutan is gradually opening up.  Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9 PM as the revised curfew. Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.  All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open starting from Monday, 21st March. All offices are to be fully operational by 11th April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Bhutan is gradually opening up.  Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9 PM as the revised curfew. Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.  All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open starting from Monday, 21st March. All offices are to be fully operational by 11th April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Bhutan has a plan for new phase of COVID 19 management. Public events are not allowed.    April 25: all sporting events will be allowed without spectators    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Taxis could ferry people within the mega zone and identified government, corporate and private employees could attend from their offices. In addition to taxis, the movement of private cars within the respective mega-zone is allowed. Those who need to drive beyond the mega-zone for emergency reasons must produce documents or any evidence for verification on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan but government recommends staying at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

All inter-district travels are allowed. Domestic travelers from high-risk areas and districts can now undergo home quarantine and not facility quarantine. The quarantine duration is seven days until further notice.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Bhutan is gradually opening up.    The quarantine period for incoming (international) travellers will be reduced to five days starting April 4. The testing protocol will be revised accordingly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

For the international travellers, the lift of the 5 days quarantine will depend on the global lifting of the pandemic as per the Prime Minister. According to the Foreign Minister and Chairman of the Tourism Council of Bhutan (TCB), the country may allow quarantine-free entry by autumn this year should the situation continue to improve.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418154933/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418154933/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There are Coordinated Public information campaigns such as National Covid-19 Outbreak Phasing Map and Covid-19 Apps.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/

PCR and/or antigen tests are generally available at the numerous flu clinics located throughout Bhutan.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151758/https://in.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/bhutan-affairs/american-citizen-services-information/

Comprehensive contact tracing is being done by National and District Surveillance Teams.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160728/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-03-22-%F0%9D%90%96%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%82%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%93%F0%9D%90%AB/

COVID-19 norms in practice, including wearing masks, avoiding gathering and hand washing must be observed at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years. After vaccinating 12-16-year-old children, Bhutan is in the process of vaccinating 5-11-year-old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old. Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418161150/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/
COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly. There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens.    https://archive.ph/5gbLt

Cases are also being reported at schools that fully reopened only last month in March after being forced shut due to the third wave again in January. However, if a fourth wave does hit India, schools, at least in the national capital, are hoping to avoid another round of full closure again. Last week, the Delhi government announced a series of measures to control the spread of the virus among school staff and students, such as wearing masks in classrooms where a student has tested positive and boosting sanitisation efforts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220425071606/https://www.edexlive.com/news/2022/apr/18/schools-in-delhi-averse-to-school-closures-as-fourth-covid-wave-looms-28370.html

'As the pandemic is subsiding the world gradually is opening up and moving back to normalcy. Organizations are asking employees to join back the offices too. However persistent health concerns and remote working as its remedy has shifted the power balance in favour of the employees. '  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425083624/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/blogs/voices/not-business-as-usual-the-post-covid19-workplace-is-a-completely-new-space-so-what-must-employers-do/

As cases spike in the national capital region (NCR), the Delhi Disaster ManageÂ­ment Authority (DDMA) held a meeting on Wednesday and decided to bring the mask-rule back. It allowed schools to continue physical classes, and there is yet no ban on social gatherings  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425091941/https://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/as-covid-cases-spike-mask-rule-and-norms-make-a-comeback-122042001399_1.html

Stricter curbs have been imposed for districts that do not meet the criteria fixed for the relaxations based on the vaccination percentage and positivity rate. Restrictions in such places include curbs on political, social and religious gatherings; a 50% occupancy cap on malls, theatres, shopping complexes, restaurants among others.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425203207/https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/mumbai-news/maha-to-lift-nearly-all-covid-19-restrictions-from-april-1-101648578281478.html

"Is public transportation operating?  Yes, though hours of operation vary throughout India depending on regional COVID-19 measures.  Please follow local media for measures in your area and verify with official Government of India sources."  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425204603/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  "Amid a steep decline in Covid-19 cases and revocation of the provisions of the Disaster Management Act by the Centre, the state government is all set to relax the majority of Covid-19 curbs from April 1. Requirements for vaccination and social distancing will be done away with. However, the use of face masks in public places will continue."  "Maharashtra has presently mandated double dose vaccination for those seeking to enter establishments, including malls and theatres, and travel by public transport."  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425203207/https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/mumbai-news/maha-to-lift-nearly-all-covid-19-restrictions-from-april-1-101648578281478.html

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, some states require either proof of COVID-19 vaccination or a current negative test result and/or testing on arrival if entering from other Indian states. Additional quarantine may be required dependent on state of origin.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425204603/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Workplaces may function at full strength. However, authorities may enact stricter rules in areas at high risk for COVID-19 transmission. Nonessential businesses, except for specifically permitted industries, must close in these localities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible. Public gatherings remain banned, though enforcement and adherence vary by region. There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

Vaccinated visitors must present a certificate showing a negative RT-PCR test, taken within 72 hours of flight of first departure.  Unvaccinated people, or those unable to show that they have been fully vaccinated for at least fourteen days, are subject to free antigen tests on arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220228212737/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/entry-requirements

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    21 more million doses to be delivered before June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    According to MoH Nepal, as of early April 2022, 75.8% of the population have received the 1st dose and 66.2% are fully vaccinated. Abour 8.1% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

All citizens aged over 12 years old are eligible to receive COVID-19 vaccines. For boosters shot eligibility criteria as follows:  1.	Immunocompromised persons of all eligible age groups  2.	Citizen, 30 years of age and above  3.	Healthcare workers.  For age group 12-18 years old only Pfizer vaccine is administered.   Available vaccines are Sinopharm, Sinovac, Pfizer and Moderna.   Vaccine is free for unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220502202916/https://covid.gov.pk/vaccine-details
